SOFT VS HARD FORKS A soft fork is a voluntary, backwards-compatible upgrade. A hard fork requires every node in the network that wants to stay active to upgrade its software. *SOFT FORK EXAMPLES* - Pay to Script Hash (P2SH) (2012) - Allowed transactions to be sent to a script hash (address starting with 3) instead of a public key hash (addresses starting with 1). Using P2SH, you can send bitcoins to an address that is secured in various unusual ways without knowing anything about the details of how the security is set up - Segregated Witness (SegWit) (2017) - Aims to reduce the size of each bitcoin transaction, thereby allowing more transactions to take place at once - Taproot (2021) - Adds support for Schnorr signatures, and improves functionality of smart contracts and the Lightning Network. Also improves privacy *HARD FORK EXAMPLES* - Bitcoin XT (2014, now dead) - increased block size from one megabyte to eight megabytes . Read The Blocksize War for more info https://discord.com/channels/874318808423219280/874326951232405554/884321844751134720 - Bitcoin Classic (2016, most have moved on) -increased block size from one megabyte to eight megabytes - Bitcoin Unlimited (2016, hasn't caught on) - allowed miners to decide on the size of their blocks, with nodes and miners limiting the size of blocks they accept, up to 16 megabytes - Bitcoin Cash (2017) - In response to SegWit, some bitcoin developers and users decided to initiate a hard fork in order to avoid the protocol updates it brought about - Bitcoin Gold (2017) - aimed to restore the mining functionality with basic graphics processing units (GPU). Also had a premine - Bitcoin SV (2018) - hard fork of Bitcoin Cash with the belief that the scalability features Bitcoin Cash had implemented were not significant enough to meet Bitcoinâ€™s ongoing requirements. Had the desire to return to the original Bitcoin design as represented in version 0.1 of the Bitcoin protocol

Today's upgrade process goes as follows: if one wants to release an incompatible client, there are two potential paths to choose from:
1. Create a new alternative coin different to Bitcoin, which does not require widespread agreement across the community; or
2. Lobby for consensus prior to advocating that anyone runs the new client. Only if widespread consensus is reached would users run the new client, and then the new coin would become known as Bitcoin.
- https://blog.bitmex.com/the-blocksize-war-chapter-1-first-strike/?__cf_chl_captcha_tk__=nTyDwOploC9qIXXLTD__gng7D6vA6qcxgNm6Eyr_4F0-1636841293-0-gaNycGzNB9E

The Bitcoin rules are not determined by changes to the software repository; they are determined by the clients which users are already running. Of course, the repository could publish new versions of the client with protocol changes, but there was no automatic upgrade feature, and nobody was forced to upgrade. 
-https://blog.bitmex.com/the-blocksize-war-chapter-2-march-to-war/#_ftn12

Anyone can write a BIP. Community can review them. Regular meetings are held and anyone can call a meeting and anyone can show up as they please. held over IRC technology - an open chat text messaging stream with moderators. BIPS are discussed, questions, tests happen on testnet. Anyone who disapproves of the change has to provide mathematical proof as to why it's a bad change.

Bitcoin is backwards compatible. So even if you and the node you run don't like a new rule/BIP, you can choose to not download the update and still get to use the same methods, protocols, wallets as everyone else on Bitcoin.
Improvements need to improve functionality and also be backwards compatible. All developers must be in agreement

The following Bitcoin softforks all required 95% miner signaling before they were implemented into the code: BIP 66 (restricting signatures to DER encoding) in July 2015, BIP 65 (Check Lock Time Verify) in December 2015, BIP 68, BIP 112, and BIP 113, all which activated in July 2016, and SegWit (provided the option for users to create transactions that couldn't be altered by malicious third parties - third party transaction malleability - which led to the lightning network)

TESTNET A testnet is a false chain for testing Bitcoin features. Three versions: - testnet (slow) - signet (a bit faster) - regtest (private, but you control everything) In regtest, mining is under your control and you get the bitcoin. Elements is a version of the Bitcoin testnet released in 2015. This is what eventually became known as Liquid sidechain which enabled Confidential Transactions (CTs).

UPCOMING UPGRADES Cross Input Signature Aggregations (SigAgg or CISA) - this could incentivize exchanges to engage in collaborative spends which would further fluster the surveillance state and make transactions hard to track Cross-input signature aggregation (CISA) could save up to 15.2% fees for 2.73 inputs and 2.8 outputs (average numbers in the Bitcoin blockchain in May 2021). In simple terms: Coinjoins *could* be cheaper than non-coinjoins.
